'''Ivárë''' was a famous [[Elves|Elven]] [[Minstrels|minstrel]], named along with [[Tinfang Warble]] and [[Daeron|Dairon]] as one of the "three most magic players of the Elves", according to the early [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref>{{LT2|I}}, p. 10</ref>

In the ''[[Gnomish Lexicon]]'' he is called a "piper of the sea",<ref name="Ior"/> possibly indicating that he was one of the [[Solosimpi]], a group of Elves who in the later legendarium became the [[Falmari|Teleri]] of [[Aman]].<ref>{{LT1|LinkC}}, p. 50</ref><ref group="note">In ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'' another name for the Solosimpi was the "Shoreland Pipers", and, as the Teleri in the later legendarium, they were closely associated with sea and music.</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Ivárë'' is [[Qenya]], but its meaning is unclear.<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-3526142297.html|articlename=ᴱQ. ''Ivárë'' m.|website=Eldamo|accessed=4 April 2022}}</ref> Its [[Gnomish]] cognate is '''''Ior'''''.<ref name="Ior">{{PE|11}}, p. 51</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In ''[[The Lay of Leithian]]'', the three greatest Elven minstrels are mentioned again as Tinfang, Dairon and [[Maglor]]; ''Maglor'' was a later change from an earlier draft, in which he replaced Ivárë.<ref>{{LB|C3}}, Commentary on Canto III, p. 182</ref>
